intro: Pseudo-oenothera virginiana, commonly known as the Virginia evening primrose, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Onagraceae family and is characterized by its showy, yellow-orange flowers that bloom in late summer and early autumn. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and have a hairy texture, while its stems are slender and branching. Pseudo-oenothera virginiana is known for its ecological importance, providing nectar for pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
